pregunta: 1. What is the recommended pneumococcal vaccination strategy for patients with rheumatic and musculoskeletal diseases (RMD) under the age of 65 who are taking immunosuppressive medication?
respuesta: The recommended pneumococcal vaccination strategy for patients with rheumatic and musculoskeletal diseases (RMD) under the age of 65 who are taking immunosuppressive medication is strongly recommended. These patients may be at increased risk of pneumococcal infection. It is advised to administer pneumococcal vaccination to all RMD patients in this category to help protect them against pneumococcal infections.

pregunta: 3. What is the recommended approach for patients with RMD who are taking rituximab in terms of timing non-live attenuated vaccine administration relative to the next dose of medication?
respuesta:
The recommended approach for patients with Rheumatic and Musculoskeletal Diseases (RMD) who are taking rituximab in terms of timing non-live attenuated vaccine administration relative to the next dose of medication is as follows:

For patients with RMD receiving rituximab, deferring non-live attenuated vaccinations, other than influenza vaccination, until the next rituximab administration is due, and delaying rituximab for 2 weeks after vaccination, is conditionally recommended.

It is important to follow this recommended approach to optimize vaccine efficacy and ensure the safety of patients with RMD who are undergoing rituximab treatment. If you have any more questions or need further information, please let me know.

pregunta: 10. Is there a difference in the seroconversion rates between younger patients with rheumatoid arthritis receiving high-dose influenza vaccination compared to standard-dose vaccination?
respuesta: Based on the retrieved documents, there is evidence indicating that younger patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) receiving high-dose influenza vaccination had higher seroconversion rates compared to those receiving standard-dose vaccination. This was demonstrated in two randomized controlled trials (RCTs) that showed higher seroconversion rates in younger patients who received high-dose vaccination with no safety concerns observed. Therefore, there appears to be a difference in seroconversion rates between younger patients with RA receiving high-dose influenza vaccination compared to standard-dose vaccination.
